facts.text: Writ Petition No. 456 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 456 of 1972. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner was an officer of the Indian Army who served in Bangla Desh.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J. The petitioner was an officer of the Indian Army who served in Bangla Desh.

facts.text: On 11th December 1971, petitioner was in Hajiganj.

anchor.surface_text: On 11th December, 1971 he was in a place called Hajiganj.

facts.text: Petitioner tried before Summary General Court Martial on charge of committing robbery at Hajiganj by causing fear of instant hurt to Custodian of United Bank Ltd. of properties of Bank, Manager and Chowkidar.

anchor.surface_text: He was tried before the Summary General Court Martial on the charge of companymitting robbery at Hajiganj by causing fear of instant hurt to the Custodian of the United Bank Ltd., of certain properties belonging to the Bank and also the personal property of the Manager of the Bank as well as of a Chowkidar of the Bank.

facts.text: Summary General Court Martial sentenced petitioner to be cashiered.

anchor.surface_text: The Court sentenced the petitioner to be cashiered.

facts.text: Maj-Gen. Hira, General Officer Commanding 23 Mountain Division, passed order directing revision of the sentence.

anchor.surface_text: Maj-Gen. Hira, General Officer Commanding, 23 Mountain Division, of which the petitioner was an officer, passed an order directing the revision of the sentence.

facts.text: Petitioner brought before same Court Martial, asked if wanted to address the Court, replied in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the petitioner was brought before the same Court Martial, as had tried him earlier, and he was asked whether he wanted to address the Court. On receiving a reply in the negative,

facts.text: Court Martial revoked earlier sentence and sentenced petitioner to be cashiered and to suffer rigorous imprisonment for two years.

anchor.surface_text: the Court, after companysidering the observations of the companyfirming authority, revoked the earlier sentence which they had imposed on the petitioner and sentenced him to be cashiered and 1027 to suffer rigorous imprisonment for two years.

facts.text: Brig. D. P. Bhilla, Officiating General Officer Commanding 23 Mountain Division, referred finding and sentence for confirmation to Chief of the Army Staff.

anchor.surface_text: Brig. D. P. Bhilla, the Officiating General Officer Commanding 23 Mountain Division, referred the finding and sentence for companyfirmation to the Chief of the Army Staff,

facts.text: Chief of the Army Staff confirmed the finding and the sentence.

anchor.surface_text: who in due companyrse companyfirmed the finding and the sentence.

facts.text: Summary General Court Martial assembled at Field on 9 March 1972 for trial of IC-16394 Substantive Lieut Actg. Capt. HARISH UPPAL, Arty, 198 Mountain Regiment.

anchor.surface_text: The Summary General Court Martial, which assembled at Field, on 9 March 1972 and subsequent days for the trial of IC-16394 Substantive Lieut  Actg. Capt.  HARISH UPPAL, Arty, 198 Mountain Regiment,

facts.text: Court Martial to reassemble on 15 May 1972 at Field at 1000 hrs for reconsidering the sentence.

anchor.surface_text: will reassemble in open companyrt on 15 May 1972 at Field at 1000 hrs for the purpose of reconsidering the sentence awarded by it,

facts.text: Maj-Gen. Hira's order directing revision dated 03 May 1972.

anchor.surface_text: Sd - D. HIRA  Maj-Gen. General Officer Commanding 23 Mtn Div. Field 03 May 1972.

facts.text: In course of six years commissioned service, petitioner convicted under Army Act Section 41(2) for disobeying lawful command, severely reprimanded on 13 June 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The present petition is filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for quashing the order passed by the Chief of the Army Staff, after setting aside the order passed by Maj-Gen. Hira.

issues.text: Whether the authority to confirm the sentence passed by a Court Martial confers on the confirming authority the power to enhance the sentence indirectly by directing the revision of the sentence?

anchor.surface_text: Shri A. K. Sen appearing on behalf of the petitioner raised four points in support of his contention that the order passed against, the petitioner should be quashed The authority to confirm the sentence passed by a Court Martial does number confer on the confirming authority the power to enhance the sentence. That authority cannot, therefore, achieve that object indirectly by directing the revision of the sentence.

issues.text: Whether the Court Martial's verdict should be unfettered and whether the confirming authority should have given a hearing to the affected party before directing revision?

anchor.surface_text: The Court Martials verdict should be unfettered. In any case, the confirming authority should have given a hearing to the affected party. The confirmation can be made only by the officer who convened the Court Martial and number by a different officer as was done in this case.

issues.text: Whether confirmation of the sentence can be made only by the officer who convened the Court Martial and not by a different officer?

anchor.surface_text: The confirmation can be made only by the officer who convened the Court Martial and number by a different officer as was done in this case. The officer who finally confirmed the sentence on the petitioner should also have heard the petitioner. The officer who convened the Summary General Court Martial,

issues.text: Whether the officer who finally confirmed the sentence on the petitioner should have heard the petitioner?

anchor.surface_text: The officer who finally confirmed the sentence on the petitioner should also have heard the petitioner. The officer who convened the Summary General Court Martial, which tried the petitioner, was Maj-Gen. Hira. It was he that directed the revision of the sentence passed on the petitioner.

issues.text: Whether in considering a petition under Article 32, the Court can examine whether any fundamental right under Article 21 has been violated?

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions of Article 136 2  of the Constitution this Court cannot grant special leave in respect of any judgment, determination or order passed or made by any companyrt or tribunal companystituted by or under any law relating to the Armed Forces. In companysidering a petition filed under Article 32 of the Constitution this Court can only companysider whether any fundamental right of the petitioner has been violated and the only Article relevant is Article 21 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The confirming authority has power under Section 160 of the Army Act to direct revision of the sentence passed by the Court Martial, which may result in enhancement if the original sentence is inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: We have already held above that the confirming authority, when he directed a revision of the sentence passed on the petitioner, was only exercising the powers conferred on him by Section 160 of the Army Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Section 160 expressly allowing revision by confirming authority; consistent with Section 158 powers to mitigate/commute but implies upward revision possible if inadequate; rejects indirect enhancement argument.

holdings.text: There is no violation of Article 21 as the procedure established by law has been completely followed.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the procedure established by law as required under that Article has been completely followed in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under Article 32 jurisdiction for armed forces matters limited to fundamental rights; examines only Article 21 compliance; facts show all Army Act procedures adhered to.

holdings.text: No principles of natural justice were violated in the revision and confirmation process.

anchor.surface_text: applying the ratio of that to the facts of this case we are not satisfied that any rule of natural justice has been violated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules of natural justice supplement but do not supplant law; depend on facts/framework; distinguishes Kraipak; opportunity given before revision court martial, petitioner declined.

holdings.text: Confirming authority not required to give hearing to petitioner before directing revision of sentence.

anchor.surface_text: To hold in the circumstances that the confirming authority should have heard the appellant before he directed the revision of the sentence passed on him would not be a requirement of principle of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory requirement; petitioner heard by court martial on revision and declined; confirming authority gave reasons but left quantum to court; natural justice not demanding pre-revision hearing.

holdings.text: Officer who convened Court Martial not the only one who can confirm or direct revision; successor or superior authority competent if holding the post.

anchor.surface_text: Section 112 of the Act which deals with the power to convene a summary general court martial shows that this attempted distinction between authority and officer is without substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 112 equates officer and authority; practical necessity (transfer/death); analogy to Article 311 (lower authority can act if competent); Brig. Bhilla officiating GOC competent.

holdings.text: No hearing required by confirming authority or referring officer before confirmation of revised sentence.

anchor.surface_text: To accept this contention would mean that all the procedure laid down by the Code of Criminal Procedure should be adopted in respect of the court martial, a contention which cannot be accepted

holdings.reasoning_summary: No requirement under Army Act; CrPC inapplicable to court martial per constitutional indications; s164 petition remedy available but not used.

holdings.text: Court cannot examine evidence or merits of findings in Army Act court martial under Article 32 jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: We must point out that this Court cannot go into the evidence in support of the charge against the petitioner. Indeed the court martial itself could not have set out the evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 136(2) bars interference with armed forces tribunals; Article 32 limited similarly to fundamental rights; court martial records findings/sentence only.

holdings.text: Order directing revision not vitiated; reasons given by confirming authority unexceptionable and left discretion to court martial.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that the reasons, given by him cannot be taken exception to. It was urged that the confirming authority proceeded on the basis that in respect of the charges

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strong language permissible as explaining inadequacy; not compelling quantum; court could reaffirm; petitioner declined to address.

precedents.case_name: A. K. Kraipak v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: rules of natural justice operate in areas not covered by any law validly made and supplement the law of the land
precedents.cited_holding: what particular rule of natural justice should apply to a given case must depend to a great extent on the facts and circumstances of that case, the frame work of the law under which the enquiry is held and the constitution of the tribunal or body of persons appointed for that purpose; enquiries must be held in good faith and without bias and not arbitrarily or unreasonably
